Sandra "Sandy" Kimbler, 72, Columbia, KY

Sandra “Sandy” Kimbler, 72, of Columbia, KY passed away peacefully on Tuesday, August 20, 2024 at her home. She was born August 15, 1952, in Adair County to the late Coakley Matney and Lillie “Polly” Banks.

She was a member of Campbellsville Baptist Temple in Campbellsville, KY. Sandy was a devoted follower of Jesus Christ, whose faith guided her throughout her life. She was a loving mother to her two sons and Grammy to her four granddaughters. She affectionately referred to her grandchildren as her “angel girls.” Her greatest blessing was her family; she often spoke of how blessed she was to have lifelong friends who enriched her life with so much love and support. She enjoyed spending time with all of her loved ones, creating the most special memories to be cherished forever. Despite the years of living in pain due to rheumatoid arthritis, she carried herself gracefully. She was a strong-willed and kind-hearted woman, always putting the needs of others before herself. She was known for her compassionate nature and witty sense of humor. Sandy will be deeply missed by all who knew her.

SURVIVORS:

2 children: Jeremy Kimbler (Jessica) and Troy Kimbler, both of Columbia

3 granddaughters: Sydney Kimbler, Sophie Kimbler, and Kaydence Kimbler

1 great-granddaughter: Lottie Jay Grant

1 brother: Ernie Matney of Columbia

1 sister: Donna Banks White (Rodney) of Columbia

A host of other special relatives & friends

Burial: Columbia Cemetery

Visitation: After 5:00 P.M. Thursday

James "Ron" Sexton, 80, Louisville, KY (Adair County Native)

James "Ron" Sexton, 80, of Louisville, KY died Saturday, August 17, 2024 at the Norton Women & Children's Hospital in Louisville. He was born on October 21, 1943 in Gradyville, KY, a son of the late Ruby and Orval Sexton.

Ron was a graduate of Adair County high school. He lived a full and vibrant life, marked by his deep love for family, dedication to his community, and diverse interests. Ron proudly served in the United States Air Force as an Airman Second Class for six years. Following his military service, he embarked on a successful career at General Electric, where he worked for 25 years. In the last 8 years of his tenure, Ron held a management position, demonstrating his leadership and commitment to excellence in the workplace.

Ron was preceded in death by his beloved wife Margaret, with whom he shared 43 wonderful years; a sister, Janice Butler; and a nephew, Eric Butler.

Ron was a devoted Past Master, 33rd degree, of the Masonic fraternity, demonstrating an unwavering commitment to its principles of brotherly love, relief, and truth. He was also an avid reader, with a particular fondness for the works of Louis L'Amour, Alistair MacLean, and Dean Koontz. An avid outdoorsman, Ron enjoyed hunting and fishing, finding joy and solace in nature. He was a passionate fan of Kentucky Wildcats basketball, rarely missing a game. In his quieter moments, Ron enjoyed challenging himself with crossword puzzles and trivia, always eager to test his knowledge and skill and learn.

SURVIVORS:

Twin stepdaughters: Kathy Thomas (Paul) and Joyce Woodrum (Brad)

1 niece: Kelly Caldwell (Joey) of Columbia, KY

Funeral Service: Friday, August 22, 2024 at 12:00pmET at Shoppenhorst, Underwood & Brooks Funeral Home, 4895 N. Preston Highway, Louisville, KY

Burial: Brookland Cemetery

Visitation: Thursday, August 21, 2024 from 4:00pm-7:00pmET and Friday after 10:00amET

In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Masonic Homes of Kentucky, a cause that was dear to Ron’s heart.

This obituary is a courtesy of Grissom-Martin Funeral Home in Columbia, KY.

Vermalene "Sugar" Grider Moore, 61, Columbia, KY

Our Lord and Savior has called home Vermalene Grider Moore, affectionately known throughout her life as “Sugar”.

Sugar was known for not only her beauty, but also her loving and kind heart. She had an infectious laugh and loved people. She loved her children, grandchildren, family members and friends. She was an excellent cook and often carried a home cooked meal to the sick and elderly.

She had a creative and artistic flair that showed in her home décor, crocheting and baking. She worked at various factories throughout her lifetime and earned her nursing degree while working at Union Underwear. She later gave up her nursing career to be available to help care for her grandsons. She was so proud of her grandsons and her devotion to them was evident. She loved talking about them to everyone she met. She liked nothing more than spending her free time at Moore’s Pool Room with the Moore family as they held a special place in her heart. Before her long and debilitating illness, she was often found helping serve customers, picking at friends and family and joyfully laughing at the jokes and tall tales bring shared there. She was a loving mother, Nina, sister and friend.

She was born January 11, 1963 and departed her earthly journey on August 19, 2024 at the age of 61. Her parents, James Grider and Allene Kerns Burton preceded her in death as well as an infant sibling and two nephews.

JoAnn Skipper, 81, Jamestown, KY

JoAnn Skipper, 81, of Jamestown, KY, passed away on Friday, August 16, 2024. She was born on November 6, 1942 in Hamilton, OH, a daughter of the late Jeff and Nancy Durbin.

JoAnn was a beloved wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. She dedicated her life to her family and her career as a registered nurse, proudly obtaining her nursing degree and caring for others throughout her life.

JoAnn enjoyed a variety of hobbies, including golf, cooking, gardening, and music ministry. She had a passion for Southern food and loved listening to the piano. In her leisure time, she also enjoyed bowling, playing cards, and participating in bingo games. JoAnn was a devoted fan of television shows like "Blue Bloods," "Big Brother," "Survivor," and "Alone", but her family was her greatest joy.

SURVIVORS:

Her loving husband: Wayne Sjipper

4 children: Greg (Rose), Gary (Margaret), Monica (Steve), and Kelley

7 grandchildren: Deena (Aaron), Justin, Dylan, Cole (Caitlyn), Lindsey, Elizabeth, and Michael

1 sister: Donna Gault

In addition to her parents, she was also preceded in death by three brothers: Edward, Roy and Mark Durbin and three sisters: Opal Gray, Edna Messer, and Rosemary Durbin.

JoAnn was a strong and determined individual, known for her unwavering faith as a devout Catholic. She found her favorite place in the world at home, surrounded by her loved ones. Her kindness, dedication, and love will be deeply missed by all who knew her.

Carl "Whitey" Mings, 75, Columbia, KY

Carl “Whitey” Mings, 75, of Columbia, KY passed away peacefully on Friday, August 16, 2024 at Russell County Hospital. He was born at home on October 22, 1948 in Columbia, KY to the late Harlin and Tolou Mings.

In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by two brothers and three sisters: Russell and Kenneth Mings, Freda Stotts, Helen Bradley and Ruby Cave.

Carl served his country in the U.S. Army during the Vietnam War, spending two years stationed in Germany. Upon his return, he embarked on a successful career as a skilled mason for four decades where he was affectionately known as “Whitey” due to his light blond hair and fair complexion. In his later years, Carl found joy on the open road driving a truck for Campbell’s Trucking and Gaskin’s Fertilizer, always accompanied by his loyal companion, Harley Pup.

An avid outdoorsman, Carl found solace in tending to his garden and casting a line in the water. He possessed a natural ability to make everyone feel at ease and his quick wit brought laughter to those closest to him. A devout member of Calvary Temple Church in the Garlin community, Carl cherished his faith and the bonds he shared with his church family.

Ivan Tucker, 86, Russell County, KY

Ivan Tucker, 86, of Russell County, KY passed away on Tuesday, August 13, 2024 at Fair Oaks Nursing and Rehabilitation in Jamestown, KY where he had been a resident for the last two years. He was born in the Parks Ridge community of Russell County on June 13, 1938 to Vernada Foster and Elijah “Giddy” Tucker.

He worked for the Formica Corporation of Cincinnati, Ohio until he was forced to retire due to illness. Ivan was a fiercely independent and a very private person who kept to himself. He was a man of extreme contrast, in that he could be stern and hard, or easy-going and compassionate toward a friend. He had an iron will and an absolute commitment to attaining his goals in life!

He was a keen observer of people, events and things- and could sum up his thoughts about each with just a few words, if asked! Ivan enjoyed Elvis Presley music, liked fast cars and talking with friends while sitting in the shade, and drinking coffee. He enjoyed the attention of the staff at Fair Oaks, who called him “Smiley” and gave him good care while he was there! Ivan professed Jesus as his Savior.

Joseph Lee Pyles, 81, Columbia, KY

Joseph Lee Pyles, 81, of Columbia, KY passed away Tuesday, August 13, 2024 at T.J. Health Columbia surrounded by his family. He was born in Adair County on January 6, 1943 to the late Finis and Marie Burton Pyles.

Joe was a 1961 graduate of Adair County High School and later Campbellsville College with a bachelor’s degree in education. He worked as a teacher at both Cane Valley and Shepherd schools in Adair County where he also served as basketball coach. He later left education to pursue his dreams of founding his own business which evolved into the diversified establishment known as Pyles Brick & Block, which he co-owned and operated with his late wife, Annabelle.

He was a charter member of Trinity Church where he remained a member and benefactor. One of his proudest professional accomplishments was working with other area businessmen to start and begin the financial institution of United Citizens Bank of Southern Kentucky. He continued to serve on the board of directors and Chair of the Loan Committee until a week prior to his passing. His greatest source of joy in life besides cutting a deal, was from his beloved family - and the successful lives of his children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. To the community, he was known as "The Brick Man", to his family, he was “Papa Joe”.
